docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1994, Paul Krugman, an economist at M.I.T., concluded that ''growing U.S. inequality and growing European unemployment are different sides of the same coin.'' The issue has only sharpened since then: America's ability to employ millions of unskilled workers -- and thereby reduce unemployment to less than half the rate in Europe without causing inflation -- is widely attributed to competitive (meaning wretched) low-end wages. But Alan Krueger, a labor economist at Princeton University who never misses a chance to debunk conventional wisdom, wonders whether economists have been too quick to buy the latest dismal science.

headline.main: Economic Scene; A new look at why the U.S. outdoes Europe in job creation.

docs.abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column discusses new theory about why United States outdoes Europe in job creation, in article by Alan Krueger and Jorn-Steffen Pischke; says most popular explanation is America's competitive low-end wages, but Krueger and Pischke say it has as much to do with vitality of small and medium-size business in US as it does with low wages; note that virtually all employment growth in recent decades in US has come from small and medium-size service businesses, and that American entrepreneurs face lower hurdles than those in Europe (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rosty is looking good. He has lost 60 pounds and had his hernia fixed. At the age of 69, he has cut down on the sirloins and the gin, and he walks as much as seven miles a day. And as of midnight Tuesday, Dan Rostenkowski is free to walk anywhere he pleases. Today one of the most influential Congressmen of the century completed a time-honored Chicago political ritual: the halfway house. Mr. Rostenkowski, a former Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, served 15 months on Federal charges of mail fraud, charges that grew out of a scandal at the House Post Office. Petty charges, too, he has argued.

headline.main: Rostenkowski, 69 and Free, Is Feeling Lighter

docs.abstract: Former Rep Dan Rostenkowski completes stay at Chicago halfway house, final part of his prison sentence for mail fraud charges growing out of House Post Office scandal; has been working to rebuild business as political consultant; his career reviewed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: While President Clinton has flatly declared ''the debate is over -- we know now that welfare reform works,'' the hard-luck counties of the Mississippi Delta show the difficulties that can emerge when tough laws collide with a weak economy. The welfare rolls have fallen sharply across this 200-mile stretch of cotton fields and catfish farms, as they have in most of the country. But with unemployment rates hovering at 10 percent or more, many of those leaving the rolls are failing to find jobs. Indeed, during one recent period, the families dropped for violating the new work rules outnumbered those placed in jobs by a margin of nearly two to one.

headline.main: WHAT ABOUT MISSISSIPPI?: A special report.; Welfare Law Weighs Heavy In Delta, Where Jobs Are Few

docs.abstract: Special report What About Mississippi focuses on impact of welfare reform and its work requirements on Mississippi Delta counties, where jobs are scarce; welfare rolls have fallen sharply in region, but many of those leaving rolls are failing to find jobs; penalties in state are nation's toughest, with those who miss appointments or decline work assignments losing entire cash grant, family's food stamps and medical insurance of adults; mothers dropped from rolls are turning to relatives, boyfriends or other Federal programs or traveling long distances in search of work; maps; graphs; photos (L)
